issue.title: Can't seem to rejoin the main chain:  Bitcoind stuck at block 422168. "Timestamp too far in future."
issue.body:
I'm not sure what is relevant so I'm including a lot of information. I'd be happy to take suggestions for ways to fix this.  I'm also posting here on the chance this is a bug or behavior that could be improved.

A log message in debug.log dated 2016-08-06 12:22:19 corresponds to about Sat Aug  6 13:22:37 CDT 2016 on my local time (`date`) while the corresponding `hwtime` shows Sat 06 Aug 2016 01:22:47 PM CDT .

```
Ubuntu 14.04.5 LTS

bitcoin-cli getinfo
{
  "version": 120100,
  "protocolversion": 70012,
  "blocks": 422168,
  "timeoffset": -26,
  "connections": 20,
  "proxy": "",
  "difficulty": 213492501107.5134,
  "testnet": false,
  "relayfee": 0.00001000,
  "errors": ""
}
```

A few weeks ago I dropped off the main chain.

```
bitcoin-cli getblockcount
422168
```

Here is the debug log from around that time. 

```
2016-07-25 03:31:17 UpdateTip: 3 of last 100 blocks have unexpected version
2016-07-25 03:31:18 UpdateTip: new best=00000000000000000304f0c7db28c15cc4226dfc491d4c4f0d8b9ae48744453a  height=422168  log2_work=85.035791  tx=144585606  date=2016-07-25 05:26:32 progress=1.000042  cache=211.6MiB(136697tx)
2016-07-25 03:31:18 UpdateTip: 3 of last 100 blocks have unexpected version
2016-07-25 03:31:18 ERROR: CheckBlockHeader(): block timestamp too far in the future
2016-07-25 03:31:18 InvalidChainFound: invalid block=000000000000000001f4de9d78ed4c2015cb676440e58069f67319ae31e71c75  height=422169  log2_work=85.035824  date=2016-07-25 05:38:02
2016-07-25 03:31:18 InvalidChainFound:  current best=00000000000000000304f0c7db28c15cc4226dfc491d4c4f0d8b9ae48744453a  height=422168  log2_work=85.035791  date=2016-07-25 05:26:32
2016-07-25 03:31:18 ERROR: ConnectTip(): ConnectBlock 000000000000000001f4de9d78ed4c2015cb676440e58069f67319ae31e71c75 failed
2016-07-25 03:31:18 InvalidChainFound: invalid block=000000000000000001f4de9d78ed4c2015cb676440e58069f67319ae31e71c75  height=422169  log2_work=85.035824  date=2016-07-25 05:38:02
2016-07-25 03:31:18 InvalidChainFound:  current best=00000000000000000304f0c7db28c15cc4226dfc491d4c4f0d8b9ae48744453a  height=422168  log2_work=85.035791  date=2016-07-25 05:26:32
2016-07-25 03:31:18 mapBlockIndex.size() = 422233
2016-07-25 03:31:18 nBestHeight = 422168
```

I have since updated my local time and hwtime (I'm not sure it was ever wrong) and restarted but I do not rejoin the main chain.

If my system clock gets out of sync and I later fix it, will I automatically rejoin the previously rejected chain?  Should this be the default behavior?

Random recent log near 'invalid header':

```
2016-07-29 01:09:26 ERROR: CheckBlockHeader(): block timestamp too far in the future
2016-07-29 01:09:26 ERROR: invalid header received
2016-07-29 01:09:26 ProcessMessages(headers, 82 bytes) FAILED peer=33

2016-07-29 01:09:59 ERROR: invalid header received
2016-07-29 01:09:59 ProcessMessages(headers, 82 bytes) FAILED peer=625
2016-07-29 01:10:32 receive version message: /bitnodes.21.co:0.1/: version 70002, blocks=422693, us=68.184.202.88:8333, peer=878
2016-07-29 01:10:32 AdvertizeLocal: advertizing address 68.184.202.88:8333
2016-07-29 01:11:04 receive version message: /Snoopy:0.2.1/: version 70001, blocks=0, us=68.184.202.88:8333, peer=879
2016-07-29 01:11:04 AdvertizeLocal: advertizing address td6iaq6jpck24fxx.onion:8333
2016-07-29 01:14:25 receive version message: /bitnodes.21.co:0.1/: version 70002, blocks=422694, us=68.184.202.88:8333, peer=880

2016-07-29 01:15:10 ERROR: CheckBlockHeader(): block timestamp too far in the future
2016-07-29 01:15:10 ERROR: invalid header received

2016-07-29 01:15:36 ERROR: invalid header received
2016-07-29 01:15:36 ProcessMessages(headers, 82 bytes) FAILED peer=625
```

events.body:
After running

```
 bitcoin-cli reconsiderblock 00000000000000000304f0c7db28c15cc4226dfc491d4c4f0d8b9ae48744453a
```

I am again downloading blocks. So it seems like after rejecting a block due to timestamping one has to manually rejoin the main chain.  Could a miner cause some portion of the network to fall off the chain in this manner?  I guess we assume clocks are well synced.  Could this be an attack vector against a node is one could change their system time?

Additionally, nothing around block 422168 changed wrt my node, so the cause of this is still unknown.


~~Did you try deleting last block and `-rescan`?~~

> Did you try deleting last block and -rescan? 

Please ignore that advice.

You can't delete a block without corrupting the database, and `-rescan` has only an effect on the wallet. The problem here seems to be with the block downloading logic.

@nathaniel-mahieu I saw this "bug" last week in the source code, but I have been unable to reproduce it on regtest, so I assumed it was just me not reading the code correctly. (My test fired the rule violation, waited 10 sec, re broadcasted, and checked if the node reconsidered, and it worked fine)
Might be related to https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/8411#issuecomment-238035612 (not about this particular rule though)

I'm not sure that this is a bug, although I do think that it could be quite simple to get bitcoind to automatically reconsider the highest block upon startup, or whenever invalid blocks are seen. Either of these solutions would fix this, I think.

@nathaniel-mahieu regarding attack vectors, yes, I think there may be a risk here in that with eclipse attacks the adjusted time could be influenced and cause a node to stop updating. With various fixes around, such as #8282 to help improve address management, and perhaps this combined with having the "adjusted time" influenced only by outbound connections (perhaps this is already what is done?), then this scenario would be much less likely to happen as far as I can see.
